doc.title: West Coast NDR: Catalyzing the Capital Freight Train
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Sempra West Coast NDR Catalyzing the Capital Freight Train Positive Meetings with Mgmt on West Coast 1 Clear Line of Sig_2025-08-29

passages.text: Positive Meetings with Mgmt on West Coast: 1) Clear Line of Sight to Accretive SIP Sale; 2) Oncor Outlook Improving via UTM, Interim Rates, & Acceleration of 765kV All Incremental to Current Plan; and 3) CA Leg Wildfire Fund Update: Still Expecting Draft Language Into Labor Day

North American Infra Story in Transition: Positive Meetings with Management: We spent two days on the West Coast hosting Sempra's CEO Jeff Martin, Executive VP Caroline Winn, Oncor's Jeff Bailey and IR Louise Bick for well attended investor meetings. We come away more positive on shares into YE25 as we see mgmt on their front foot with line of sight to an EPS / credit accretive SIP sale announcement, while we remain in the final innings of a AB 1054 wildfire fund extension. Further, since mgmt set the plan for Texas on the 4Q24 call, achieving an interim rate settlement helps derisk the case materially in our view, while there could be a path towards a 45% equity capital structure and Oncor CapEx is seemingly accelerating by the day. We provide key takeaways below.

Growth Rate Communication: 7- 9% at High End, Before Contemplating Numerous Upside Levers: We found commentary on where mgmt can take the growth rate over the next year as outright bullish as mgmt sees themselves being able to execute at the high end or above their projected 7- 9% EPS CAGR before contemplating the UTM tracker in Texas, \(\) 12bn\(of additional CapEx upside from Oncor, and SIP asset sale accretion. Street and Barclays EPS estimates are roughly in line with this view, though as mgmt continues to execute this year, and gives an updated view of SIP accretion in 3Q/4Q, there could be a path for consensus EPS revisions in the back half of this year. Longer term on the growth rate we see mgmt as remaining conservative but setting the story up to consistently outperform the high end of the 7- 9% long term EPS expectations, and it does appear mgmt will work to provide a new plan in early 2026, which should show another increase in long term CapEx, which depending on the outcome of the SIP sale, may not require ongoing common equity issuance. The new plan could come in the form of a higher 26 / 2 base EPS in our view that mgmt then grows off of at a 7- 9% rate. A common question after the 4Q rebase was when does mgmt's new growth rate outlook intersect with the old plan where mgmt does seem well positioned to exceed expectations.

Oncor: More than Just a DC Play & Well Positioned on Transmission: Oncor has \(\sim 200GWs\) of total load requests on the system compared to a peak system load of 31GWs while there is also 19GWs of non- DC demand (Wafer, Ethane Crackers, heavy industrial manufacturing) in the service territory. Mgmt is mostly solving these needs with new transmission where we learned: 1) ERCOT T&Ds have properly secured the supply chain for 765kV builds, comparing to proposals
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 5. Completed: 29- Aug- 25, 12:24 GMT Released: 29- Aug- 25, 12:25 GMT Restricted - External
U.S. Power & Utilities
Potential Upside/Downside - 1.8% Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
U.S. Power & Utilities

being put forward in other ISOs (PJM); 2) Permian / West Texas projects, that have been slated for the mid- 2030s have seen requests at ERCOT to be pulled forward to 2030, representing a significant acceleration of a portion of the Texas transmission expansion opportunities outlined on the 2Q call; and 3) these opportunities, while they receive state level returns, are relatively easy to execute on from a permitting and CCN standpoint (6 months) when compared to those for other competitive transmission companies across ISOs (PJM / MISO).

Oncor Rate Case: Interim Rates Underappreciated... Watching PUCT Approval: Recall Oncor filed its electric rate case back in late June, requesting an increase in revenue requirement of \(\) 834\mathrm{mm}\(, predicated on 10.55% ROE and 45% equity layer, compared with the last approved rate case back in early 2023, with authorized ROE of 9.7% and equity layer of 42.5%. On August 12, as part of the agreed procedural schedule, Oncor agrees to waive the 12/29/2025 statutory deadline for the commission to issue a final order, with parties agreeing to an interim rate (D&A, Cost of Debt, Storm Cost recoveries), and a new targeted PFD was set for 3/3/2026. Parties (including Staff and most of the intervenors, including large industrials) agreed on Oncor's existing rates becoming interim rates effective 1/1/2026, and being subject to refund or surcharge based upon the final rates approved by the Commission. We expect the commission to approve this structure for interim rates in the next few weeks, while this changes the set up for a settlement in our view into year end. The current procedural schedule includes intervenor direct testimony on 10/17, staff direct testimony on 10/24, with hearings to start on 11/17 through 11/21. The agreement on interim rates is a fundamental change in Texas which we think puts the company in a better negotiating position through the case, and takes the risk off there being rate lag starting in Jan 1, 2026, while Oncor we think could still settle on ROE / capital structure by year end. We note our current model assumes a 9.7% ROE / 43.5% equity layer, and every 100bps of equity capital structure movement translates to \(0.05 / sh\) of EPS, or 1% of consolidated SRE EPS. We do sense from our trip there is clear upside to Texas capital structure over time, perhaps beyond our 43.5% assumption.

Oncor ROE Improvement with UTM: Critical Positive as Mgmt Set to Accelerate Texas Capital: We see the current earned ROE at Oncor near at a high 7% for 2025 vs. the 9.7% authorized and we believe the UTM is worth \~100bps, where the new base rate review should true mgmt up closer to the authorized in year 1 of new Oncor rates. In a pre- UTM environment the base plan did contemplate significant lag as mgmt was set to execute on \~14% rate base growth which we see growing to high teens (\~17%) as Oncor is likely to target a significantly larger capital plan in the upcoming 4Q refresh. We're unsure if the entire \(\) 12\$ bn of capital makes it into the next 5yr Texas plan however we think its safe to assume \~ \(\) 2- 3bn/yr increases starting in 2027, in our view.

California: Expecting Wildfire Fund Clarity Into Labor Day: Mgmt did note that redistricting efforts in the state slightly impacted the timeline for the wildfire fund fix, but it does seem that draft legislation is expected to be put forward imminently. We expect an update on legislation soon, and we believe an outcome in line with the Newsom draft proposal would be viewed quite positively. Recall SRE's share of contributions for recapping the fund would be limited to \(4.3\%\) of the total IOU contribution, and while this event is more impactful to EIX / PCG, we view it as important for how investors are approaching SRE's SOTP story.

Addressing Perceived Wildfire Risk: The CA comps have been a problem for SRE's SOTP valuation with peers (EIX / PCG) trading near 9.0x forward earnings vs. the sector average at 16.6x, although mgmt sees itself as well insulated at SDG&E given the system is \(60\%\) undergrounded (highest next to ConEd in sector) while they have made the investments in wildfire hardening much earlier than peers. We note SDG&E's early adoption of wildfire technologies, situational awareness and hardening strategies have served as the gold standard across the industry. The territory is also 1/9 the size of the peers to the north of the company.

SIP Sale Accretion: We See it Likely Mgmt Targets \(30\%\) or More, Driving Pro Forma Earnings to 90/10 Reg / Non- Reg Mix: Recall mgmt on the 2Q call noted they signed a non- binding letter of intent with one of the current SIP owners for an additional equity sale in SIP. Mgmt previously noted they expect to sell \(15 - 30\%\) of their current ownership \((70\%)\) . Discussions in our meetings pointed to a sale outcome in the Fall, while we're unsure if it will be after or before the 3Q call, we expect mgmt to communicate this as an EPS and credit accretive transaction. We also think it's possible mgmt could host a special call post the announcement, framing the pro forma accretion investors should expect, which we see as a positive catalyst. We include our latest accretion / dilution math below for a \(30\%\) stake, see it as \(3.4\%\) accretive to EPS and a \(1\%\) increase to FFO/debt, assuming proceeds go towards half debt pay down and half to offset equity needs currently in our model.

Selling SIP Stake Will Catalyze Credit While Simplifying SRE's Story: We see Sempra selling down their SIP stake as critical to unlocking the growth at Texas where mgmt is clearly vying to put a plan in front of investors that targets no new major equity issuance, net of upcoming capital plan increases which could be unveiled sometime in early 2026 (4Q call). Paying down debt with proceeds while re- investing proceeds into Texas should allow for ample credit

headroom above a new agency minimum. Mgmt we think will be targeting more cushion to it's new FFO/debt minimum which could be in the 13- 14% range if they're able to successful execute on this portfolio recycling. We see the agencies giving the company time to meet its targeted minimums and execute on the transition if announced this Fall.

SRE Catalyst Path from Here: We see the catalyst path as follows: 1) SIP Equity Stake: Recall mgmt has \(3 - 4bn of asset sales in the current financing plan, while we think they could announce at least\) 7bn of proceeds from a 30% stake sale in SIP (12.0x assumed EBITDA) sometime this Fall; 2) PA2 FID by Year End: Sempra Infra has consistently announced new SPAs / HOAs for this asset with the timeline of FID by YE is becoming more real. Mgmt is now at 7.5 MTPA subscribed vs \~12.5 nameplate, although we think getting to 10 could trigger FID; 3) Oncor Rate Settlement: 4Q25- 1Q26 we think Oncor could execute on a settlement which should include a higher allowed equity layer; and 4) LT Update: Around the 4Q call, we think mgmt can provide a new long term EPS outlook, including refreshed FY26 guidance and introducing FY27 while taking the capital plan out to 2030.

SIP EPS / Credit Illustrative Math: Both positive: We re- run our scenario for the company to sell down 30% of SIP ownership, assuming 12x EV/EBITDA (midpoint of 11x- 13x, based on historical transactions and current comparables) - see here. We see this potentially leading to sales proceeds of \~\$7.4bn, and if SRE uses 50% of the proceeds to avoid equity issuance, and the rest of the 50% for debt pay- down (assume 5% CoD), it would be both EPS and credit accretive, with 3.4% accretion on EPS and 1% on FFO/debt improvement. We re- iterate our estimates on SIP, including EBITDA composition (Cameron LNG of \~\$750mm, ECA Phase 1 and PA Phase 1 together contribute \~\$700mm, Energy Network of \~\$550mm, Low Carbon Solution of \~\$200mm, Debt at SRE level, Cameron LNG of \$3.8bn, ECA Phase 1 LNG of \$1.1bn, PA Phase 1 LNG of \$1.1bn, Energy Network and Low Carbon totaling \$2.5bn debt, and SIP Ownership, Cameron Phase 1 of 50.2%, ECA Phase 1 of 83.4%, PA Phase 1 of 28%).
FIGURE 2. SIP 30% Sell-down EPS/Credit Impact (for illustrative purposes only)

U: The equity securities of this Canadian issuer include subordinate voting restricted shares.
V: The equity securities of this Canadian issuer include non- voting restricted shares.
Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

**Valuation Methodology:** Our price target of $65 is based on a SOTP analysis in which we use P/E multiples to value the parts. We value SCE and parent EPS based on an 30% discount to the 2027E large-cap peer electric multiple. We see this as properly reflecting the California discount given wildfire risk but recent constructive TKM settlement agreement for cost recovery.

**Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target:** Failure to achieve constructive rate outcomes in the 2025 GRC or track 4 proceeding, future wildfire events, inflation, and rise or decline in interest rates.

**Valuation Methodology:** Our PT is $20, which is based on a SOTP model using P/E multiples to value the parts. We value PCG and Parent EPS based on a 30% discount to the 2027E large-cap electric peer multiple. We believe this properly handicaps for the potential impairment of the wildfire fund,which is a liquidity vehicle for PCG.

**Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target:** Better/worse than expected regulatory outcomes, failure to achieve a constructive outcome in CoC filing, efficient financing strategies, or cost containment efforts as well as wildfire event risk.

Valuation Methodology: Our PT is \(\) 80\(and we value shares on a SOTP basis employing a relative P/E approach for the electric utilities and parent, an EV/EBITDA approach for SIP and an NPV approach for LNG projects in service past the valuation year. We note the following assumptions across businesses: Utilities: We apply a 25% discount to the FY27 Electric group multiple for SDG&E and 15% discount for SCG. At Texas, we assume a in-line multiple. Sempra Infrastructure Partners (SIP): We take SRE's 70% share of SIP 2026 EBITDA at an 12.0x multiple. Incremental LNG Value: We value SRE's proportional share in the NPV value of Cameron 4 and PA 1 which employ 9.28% discount rate.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Risks our rating and shares includes wildfire risk, natural disaster risks associated with operating electric and gas transmission lines, regulatory outcomes.
Third Party Distribution: Any views expressed in this communication are solely those of Barclays and have not been adopted or endorsed by any third party distributor.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

Any information, data, image, or other content including from a third party source contained, referred to herein or used for whatsoever purpose by Barclays or a third party ("Information"), in relation to any actual or potential 'ESG', 'sustainable' or equivalent objective, issue, factor or consideration is not intended to be relied upon for ESG or sustainability classification, regulatory regime or industry initiative purposes ("ESG Regimes"), unless otherwise stated. Nothing in these materials, including any images included therein, is intended to convey, suggest or indicate that Barclays considers or represents any product, service, person or body mentioned in these materials as meeting or qualifying for any ESG or sustainability classification, label or similar standards that may exist under ESG Regimes. Barclays has not conducted any assessment of compliance with ESG Regimes. Parties are reminded to make their own assessments for these purposes.
